titles.title: A bill to designate the United States courthouse that is scheduled to be constructed in Concord, New Hampshire, as the "Warren B. Rudman United States Courthouse", and for other purposes.

action.text: Sponsor introductory remarks on measure. (CR S5188-5189)
Read twice and referred to the Committee on Environment and Public Works.

committee.name: Committee on Environment and Public Works

calendar.text: Committee on Environment and Public Works. Ordered to be reported without amendment favorably.

action.text: Committee on Environment and Public Works. Reported to Senate by Senator Baucus without amendment. Without written report.

calendar.text: Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 568.

vote.text: Passed Senate without amendment by Voice Vote.

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on Public Works + Transportation.
Message on Senate action sent to the House.

committee.name: House Committee on Public Works + Transportation

action.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Public Buildings and Grounds.
Committee on Public Works + Transportation discharged.
Mr. Traficant asked unanimous consent to discharge from committee and consider.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
The title of the measure was amended. Agreed to without objection.
Message on House action received in Senate and at the desk: House amendments to Senate bill.
Senate agreed to the House amendments by Voice Vote. (consideration: CR 10/7/94 S14960)
Message on Senate action sent to the House.

bill.summary: 10/7/1994--Passed House amended. Designates: (1) the United States courthouse to be constructed in Concord, New Hampshire, as the Warren B. Rudman United States Courthouse; and (2) the Federal building located at the northeast corner of the intersection of 14th Street and Independence Avenue, Southwest, Washington, D. C., as the Jamie L. Whitten Federal Building; and (3) the Federal building and United States courthouse located at 242 East Main Street in Bowling Green, Kentucky, as the William H. Natcher Federal Building and United States Courthouse.
